bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 11, 1918

div1.p: Gorgas reports to Kean that Pershing recommends sending the remaining men at Allentown to France. Gorgas approves of Kean's administration.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 11, 1918
div1.opener:
wcg-hhw
S. G. O. 201 45-1,8
WAR DEPARTMENT
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
WASHINGTON
February 11, 1918.
Colonel Jefferson R. Kean,
United States Army,
American Expeditionary Forces,
France.
My dear Kean:
div1.p:
The ambulance question is at present in this position:
The Chief of Staff has cabled Pershing suggesting that we send
over all the remaining sections at Allentown to be taken up
and used in our army as needed. This is practically what you
recommend, though we have had no cable from Pershing to that
effect.

I think that you have done just right about the ambulances
and have managed the whole affair exceedingly well.

I send Captain Doyle to you as you request. I think that
you have a wrong opinion of him in thinking that he has been dis-
loyal to you. Probably I am at fault. I several times told him
to cable to Andrews and find out what you wanted. I could get
no reply from Pershing and was entirely in the dark as to what
was desired. I think him one of the most capable, energetic,
young fellows we have gotten from civil life.

I agree with you that your present work is about as useful
as anything you can do and have no intention of making any change.
Mrs. Gorgas joins in kindest regards.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, W. C. Gorgas. ALL COMMUNICATIONS SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO “THE SURGEON, GENERAL U. S. ARMY, WASHINGTON D. C.”
